issue.title: When python opens up after a few seconds I Get the text below.
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
[A clear and concise description of the bug]

**Steps to Reproduce**
1.
2.[Window Title]
devenv.exe

[Main Instruction]
An unexpected error occurred

[Content]
Please press Ctrl+C to copy the contents of this dialog and report this error to our issue tracker.

[V] Show details  [Close]

[Expanded Information]
```
Build: 17.0.23189.3

System.ObjectDisposedException: Cannot access a disposed object.
   at Microsoft.VisualStudioTools.Project.ProjectNode.GetMsBuildProperty(String propertyName, Boolean resetCache)
   at Microsoft.VisualStudioTools.Project.ProjectNode.GetProjectProperty(String propertyName, Boolean resetCache)
   at Microsoft.PythonTools.Project.CondaEnvCreateProjectInfoBar.<CheckAsync>d__4.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at Microsoft.PythonTools.Infrastructure.VSTaskExtensions.<HandleAllExceptions>d__5.MoveNext()
```
3.

**Expected behavior**
[A clear and concise description of your expectation]

**Additional context and screenshots**
[Add any other information such as screenshots, error message, or stack trace]

**Sample Code**
```
XXX
```

**Configuration information (If you are providing a diagnostics file (see below), skip this section)**
VS Version: [Can be found under "Help->About Microsoft Visual Studio"]
PTVS version: [Can be found under "Help->About Microsoft Visual Studio->Installed products->Python with Pylance"]
Python version:
Debugger Type (if applicable): [New debugger or legacy debugger?]

**Diagnostics file**
The diagnostics file contains information such as the Python version, environments, loaded assemblies, configuration options, etc. This file makes it easier for us to reproduce and fix bugs, so we would really appreciate it if you could provide it to us. To locate the logs, you can can follow these steps:
1. Open the File Explorer on your computer.
2. In the address bar at the top of the window, type %TEMP% and press Enter.
3. The %TEMP% folder should open, look for file named PythonToolsDiagnostics_*.log, where * represents a series of numbers.

This file contain the diagnostic information that can help us diagnose and resolve the issue you're experiencing.
Please note that the %TEMP% folder is a hidden system folder, so you may need to enable the display of hidden files and folders in File Explorer to see it. To do this, click on the "View" tab in File Explorer, then check the "Hidden items" box in the "Show/hide" section.
You can attach the file to this issue or email it to us at ptvshelp@microsoft.com. If you email it, please add a link to this issue.
```
XXX
```

issue.title: Autocomplete after open brackets replaces entire line of code
issue.body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Autocomplete-after-open-brackets-replace/1582855)._ --- [severity:It bothers me. A fix would be nice] [regression] [worked-in:Visual Studio 2019 v. 16.11.6] Visual Studio Community 2022 Current v. 17.0.0 (Windows) in conjunction with the Python extension contains the following bug: If auto-completion / IntelliSense is used after open brackets, not only the word is completed and inserted, but the entire line of code is deleted and overwritten with the word. Simple example: _testword = "This is a test." print (testw ... #use of IntelliSense leads to ==> **testword**_ The bug does not occur in Visual Studio Community 2019 (Python) and Visual Studio Code (Python). --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 11/15/2021, 00:17 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

issue.title: Prepare Visual Studio to Handle Python Version 3.12
issue.body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Prepare-Visual-Studio-to-Handle-Python-V/10481415)._

---
As of September 19, the Python Foundation "strongly encourage[s] maintainers of third-party Python projects to prepare their projects for 3.12 compatibilities." ([source](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3120rc3/))

As Visual Studio is a professional tool for programmers, I believe it is appropriate for Visual Studio to handle new version updates, especially for major releases of any supported language. 

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 10/2/2023, 09:49 AM: 

(private comment, text removed)

issue.title: Numpy array content not displayed fully in preview version
issue.body:
In the recent preview versions the displays of numpy arrays has been changed so that it is impossible to see the content of longer arrays as they get cut-off:
![image](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/52322342/f3d86729-ef72-4c03-b274-ccaac93a5892)

In the regular version (screenshot from Version 17.7.5), the content of the same variable can be accessed by scrolling vertically.
![image](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/52322342/401f49b7-a3ea-4d7c-89e5-737ef7802df4)

Removing the functionality to display longer arrays is ill-conceived. Please add back.

issue.title: Add python interpreter from WSL
issue.body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Add-python-interpreter-from-WSL/10080853)._

---
Currently, Visual Studio 2022 allows to add python interpreters installed locally in Windows. It would be nice the option to add python interpreters installed in WSL. Some developers like me work on WSL with C++, and many times we mix both python and C++

---

issue.title: Custom task list token in Visual Studio 2022 doesn't work for Python.

labels.name: fixed in next version
labels.description: A fix has been implemented an will appear in an upcoming version

issue.body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Custom-task-list-token-in-Visual-Studio-/10133217)._

---
Hi Team,

I found that my custom task list tokens don't work in VS 2022 for Python(But it works in VS 2019).

**Steps to reproduce:**

1. Open VS 2022, create a Python project.
2. In Tools > Options > Environment > Task List > input a new name for example "Test1" > click Add to add this custom task list token.
3. In .py file > input some comments for example "#Test1: this is a test" > save the project.
4. Click View > Task List.
5. In Task List window, the Test1 task list token doesn't appear.

You can test in C# projects, or in VS 2019 Python projects, they should work well.

If it's a potential issue, please fix it.

Thanks

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 8/29/2022, 02:23 AM: 

(private comment, text removed)

---
### Original Solutions
(no solutions)

comment.body:
Just for the record:
VS Version 17.4.4 (Win x64) up to date.

Neither TODO, nor custom markers are picked up - the task list is empty.

issue.title: VS crash when editing
issue.body:
When editing copying code or using ctrl-x crashes VS which gets stuck displaying a message box "copy - Formatting selection". This happens when not waiting until the status message "x files to analyze" disappears and "Python analysis done" shows.

![image](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/52322342/d0668251-5e4f-4b73-95fa-8e2c81001acb)

comment.body: In some instances the message is: "Please wait for an editor command to finish"

issue.title: Updated to full version, can no longer read .cs files
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
[A clear and concise description of the bug]

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Get trial version of Visual Studio 2022 Pro
2. Company purchases full version of Visual Studio Pro
3. Reopen Visual Studio 2022 Pro after installing and updating to full version

**Expected behavior**
I expected to use the product as normal. Now all my .csproj have (incompatible) next to them. I click on them and underneath they say "The application is not installed."

VS Version: 17.7.5

comment.body: Can you go the your Visual Studio installer and share which workloads have you installed in that version?

comment.body:
Hi there, it seems the problem occurs when the CPython installer fails. This could be due to network timeouts, corporate firewall policy, VPN configuration, anti-virus, or other problems. See if a retry helps, and if not, see if you can download the Python runtime directly from https://python.org/ and install it manually.

If that doesn't solve your issue, we could use more detailed logs to see what's really going on. Can you please collect more logs by running http://aka.ms/vscollect.exe and uploading %temp%\vslogs.zip and reopen the ticket if it persists? Thank you!😊

issue.title: Unable to disable python exceptions
issue.body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Unable-to-disable-python-exceptions/10489861)._

---
[severity:It's more difficult to complete my work] [regression] [worked-in:vs2019]
In VS2022, I'm unable to disable any python exceptions.
If a debugger is attached, it will break on every single exception even the benign ones. Which makes debugging impossible with certain scripts that use exceptions part of non-erroneous executions.
I tried disabling/enabling all in the exceptions window. No impact either way.
I tried different python versions. no impact.
I tried unchecking the "new exception helper". I get a different exception window (btw, much more helpful than the "new" one), but the "break when ..." is greyed out. So I can't disable an exception from there either.
I played with other options, no luck.

Vs2019 had a similar issue, but if i remember correctly, it had a "use legacy debugger" option, which I think ended up resolving this issue. Unfortunately, you removed that option.

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 10/12/2023, 04:02 AM: 

(private comment, text removed)

---
### Original Solutions
(no solutions)

commits.message:
Fix warning that repeatedly shows up (#7731)

* update versions exposed to users

* fix warning repeatedly showing up

* update debugpy version

issue.title: There is a warning that repeatedly shows up
issue.body:
**Environment**
![image](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/59192491/b427c82f-baf0-4d11-bf89-e1e697c075b2)


**Steps to Reproduce**
1.Create a python project
2.Create a conda environment
3.Check python version if is 3.12

**Actual behavior**
There is a warning pops up and I need close it more than one time
![image](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/59192491/1282d22d-55b2-49e8-a3d9-174b7b215e78)

![conda_py32](https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/assets/59192491/68057ab9-5bec-4a5b-b56f-ea0cd11eb7f7)


**Expected behavior**
I can close it in one time

pull_request.title: Fix warning that repeatedly shows up
pull_request.body:
fixes https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/issues/7728

The warning pops up if the python version > 3.11. Currently the python version check runs every time ptvs sends new settings to pylance. The fix is to move the version check to whenever the activated environment changes.

issue.title: Fix warning that repeatedly shows up
issue.body:
fixes https://github.com/microsoft/PTVS/issues/7728

The warning pops up if the python version > 3.11. Currently the python version check runs every time ptvs sends new settings to pylance. The fix is to move the version check to whenever the activated environment changes.
